{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3130099,"name":"Sriman Achanta","username":"Spirit-540","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-19T23:17:42.800Z","cooked":"

Hello, my team wants to use retroreflective targets and April tags this year. Because of this, we need LEDs in order to illuminate the retroreflective targets. We were thinking of using the LEDs on AndyMark here. The issue with this is that these LEDs require a 12v input (according to the docs) and the raspberry pi used to drive Photon doesn’t have a 12v rail. How could be use raspberry pi to turn the 12v connection to the LEDs on and off?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-01-19T23:17:42.800Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":26,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":149.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423952,"topic_slug":"control-andymark-ring-leds-with-photonvision","display_username":"Sriman Achanta","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.andymark.com/products/led-ring-green","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51645,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming"},"post_url":"/t/control-andymark-ring-leds-with-photonvision/423952/1","custom_user_title":"Programming","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3130105,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-19T23:28:40.742Z","cooked":"

Check out Playing With Fusion - SnakeEyes (Green) Visible Raspberry Pi HAT for FRC Robotic Vision if you haven’t seen it yet.

The alternate would be assembling a circuit which can be switched by some signal-level output (3.3v? 5v? PWM? constant on-off?) and modulate high current 12v power into the LED. I’m not sure I have a great recommendation other than the snakeyes unit above, or just a relay.

A few options:

  • Use Addressable LEDs (controlled by the RIO) instead of a simple 12V strand–advantage is you can pick a unique color combination for color filtering, disadvantage is they might not be as bright
  • Use a N-channel MOSFET to switch the LEDs with a DIO pin (potentially set up for duty cycle PWM, which the Rio supports, not sure about the Pi). E.g. SparkFun MOSFET Power Controller - PRT-11214 - SparkFun Electronics

The Rev PDH has a switchable channel that you can turn on and off in your robot code. The switchable channel is PDH port 23. You can control it using this code: Power Distribution Module — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
